item.description:
Description: Those pesky bugs just keep coming at you! Your job is to SWAT them right when they score the most points. But be quick or your fellow players will SWAT them first.

SWAT! is about capturing cards. A dealer turns over cards one-by-one, until someone decides he wants the exposed cards and hits the colorful "SWAT!" board. That player then becomes the dealer and the same process continues until all players have "swatted" three times or the deck runs out. Your challenge is to remember what you have already swatted and decide how far you can push your luck before another player swats the stack. The artwork is fun, imaginative and might get a little bit under your skin!

item.description:
Simple board wargame on the July 14, 1808 Peninsular War battle between a French corps commanded by Bessières and the Army of Galicia under the joint command of Blake and La Cuesta.

Published in Casus Belli (Issue 19 - Feb 1984) magazine.

1 map sheet, 17x26 hexes map + charts
60 unmounted counters
rules

- French Combat
- Spanish Movement
- Spanish Combat
- Reorganization

Rules Notes:

- Locking Active Zones of Control

item.description:
Villin Lännen Poppamies (Finnish for "The Medicine Man of the Wild West") is played on a map of North America. It is similar to the classic Finnish game "Afrikan Tähti" but here the objective is to find the token for the Medicine Man on the map and deliver him back to Washington (from where all players start) to win the game.

The players travel on the roads/waterways between cities where they flip tokens to reveal indians or military/settlers. The game uses rifles as its currency, to protect the players from hostile indian tokens flipped over or to pay tolls for crossing borders or using waterways.

Vicky the Viking based boardgame in which the players try to obtain diamonds. There are several phases in which the players place one of their hand cards on a personal board, then all cards in that particular position are compared and the winner gets a diamond (bounty depends on the position of the card on the board, winning depends on different symbols on the cards). 
Defeated cards are always discarded, victorious cards stay on the board until defeated. When the first player has collected seven diamonds, he/she is the winner.

name.value: Star Wars R2-D2 is in Trouble

item.description:
Help Anakin Skywalker and C-3PO race around the chamber to save R2-D2 from the force field! Give the bubble a pop to get Artoo on his feet! With Artoo's help, you can fly around the board at galactic speed, bring out another pawn to help you, or bump one of your opponents' back before they do it to you! name.value: Monopoly Get Out of Jail Mini Game

item.description:
Contents:
Jail base and 4 jail walls
24 prisoners (3 of each in 8 different colors)
6 prison guards
1 spade

Prisoners and guards are placed in the jail cell and in turn, each player manipulates the spade underneath the cell and through slats in the floor of the cell in an attempt to flick out prisoners of different colors. Don't free a prison guard, or you're busted!
This game has a push-your luck component (players may stop flicking at any time and keep their freed prisoners, but if a prison guard is flicked out, all freed prisoners are returned and that player's turn is over) and a set collection mechanic (collect 3 prisoners of any individual color for double points).

This game can be played as a stand-alone game, or can be combined with any Monopoly game as an alternative to rolling doubles to get out of jail.

The game is fun for the entire family. Object of the game is to score the most "braggin' rights" which are similar to points. Each game piece is your boat, and the path of the game takes your around the lake. Starting at the cabin, you roll the dice. If you land on a "Fish On!" space, you select a lure and start fishing. Depending on the size and species of fish, you collect the "braggin' rights". Other spaces include a "Fishing Duel", where the player chooses another player to a duel, the biggest fish wins. Look out, not all the spaces are rewarding! The player who finishes the day with the most "braggin' rights" wins.

The little penguins are striving to stay atop a melting iceberg. Unfortunately the body heat of the penguins is melting the ice. Who can stay afloat the longest?
Each player will take on the role of a penguin. On your turn, you will make a move, then remove (or melt) the spot that you left. If you can't make a legal move then you're out of the game. Last player on the iceberg wins!

Promotional trivia game from the Swedish bureau of statistics. The game features a simple push your luck mechanic: two teams take turns to answer questions and can stop at 1 point for one correct answer or attempt to gain 3 points by answering two questions in succession.

The pack of cards in the 2009 edition includes around 100 questions related to Swedish statistics in the years 2006-2008, e.g. "How many babies were born in 2007 on the day of that year when the least number of babies were born?" Unlike the typical trivia game, answers are accompanied by additional related trivia or historical comparisons.

Later editions seem to have dropped the rules, leaving the "game" as just a deck of questions, and have fewer notes to accompany the answers.

item.description:
Chester Gump Game, In the City of Gold
Another simple roll and move game from the Milton Bradley series of games based on the comic strip character of the times.
Skeezix and the Air Mail A simple roll and move game from the Milton Bradley series of games based on the comic strip character of the times. This game is circa 1930's

name.value: Spanky Spanky: The Hanky Panky Game

item.description:
This is an ADULT party game with strong sexual content.

Players represent students at the Academy of Sweet Suffering (A.S.S.) and must attempt to move up the academic ladder to graduate... hopefully while receiving just a few spankings.

Each pupil starts the game in the locker room and advances along the path on the game board by answering questions correctly. Wrong answers result in the student getting a "black mark" score chip and three chips equals a spanking. The contestants take turns serving as the "Spankmaster General" to administer the punishments.

Various event cards guide the flow of the game, including domination and submission cards. The first player to travel up the ladder three times is declared the winner.

Includes board, cards, die, rules, scoring tokens, and a toy whip with a feather tickler!

Designed for 2 to 8 players or 2 to 4 teams.

Pictureka! rolls into 9 changeable cubes and 3 great games! The find it fast, find it first cube game!

Contents include 18 interchangeable cube halves (9 blue, 9 white), 1 game grid, 40 cards and instructions.

Each mission card tells you what to look for on the cubes.
Game 1: Split up the cubes and search for pictures on your own set.
Game 2: Everyone search all visible sides of the cubes, but don't lay a finger on them.
Game 3: Pick blue or red cubes. Spot the pictures and move all your team's cubes to the other side of the game grid first!

-Includes a 4th game--great for younger kids

100 Points Rummy is a simple, casual card game in the 100 Points line of games that uses 100 Points cards.

In 100 Points Rummy players try to get a four-card hand totaling 100 points. Each time they do, they score the hand. The first player with 400 points wins the game.

The game can be played with 2 or more players.

You need 1 set of 100 Points cards per player to play the game.

Rat Race is a fast-paced card game about big business. Payers hire Clients and Employees, win Contracts, and use their Big Bucks to buy Perks for their office.

On each turn, you collect income from your Clients, plus your base income of one buck each turn. You may attempt to play one Contract each turn for additional income. Next, play as many cards from your hand as you can afford. You can hire more Clients who boost your future income, hire Employees who increase your Status and protect you from certain Events, and you can play Events to trash or steal your opponents' best stuff.

You also buy Perks for your office, which is what gives you the most game-winning Status points. Upgrade your metal desk to a Mahogony Desk. Enjoy the view from your 40th story window. Spruce up the place with a Private Washroom, Masseuse, or an Objet D'Art. If you complete a 3x3 office, you also get a 3-point bonus.

Once the draw deck is empty, each player adds up his or her Status Points. The player with the highest Status total wins.

Official website:
http://www.wunderland.com/WTS/Chort/ratrace/index.html

item.description:
Gogo's Crazy Bones are a collectible, mini game toy sensation. They are small, colorful figures whose gaming origins date back to Ancient Greece where children played by bouncing and throwing knuckle bones.

Many different games can be created using Crazy Bones, but there are instructions for several games available in various Crazy Bones publications. Among them are:

Scoring: Throw five Crazy Bones and score for how they land.
On Line: Throw Crazy Bones as close to a line as possible.
Battle: Line up a bunch of Crazy Bones across from another opponent and flick them into each other. Last one standing wins.
K.O.: Stand Crazy Bones inside a circle. Use other Crazy Bones to knock them out.
In Flight: Throw a Crazy Bones in the air and try to pick up others on the ground and catch the thrown Crazy Bones before it hits the ground.
Basket: Throw Crazy Bones into or through a target.

item.description:
Players are merchants in the colonial U.S., trading wares such as maize, tobacco, animal pelts, weapons and alcohol with Native American villages. In some villages, you trade your wares for other wares. In other villages, for your wares, you receive wampum--bands of shells and beads used as currency by American Indians--and subsequently the white European settlers as well. The types of wares you are trading and the types in the village where you are trading determine whether you will get wares or wampum.

Clever trading in the right village at the right time is the key to collecting the most wampum and winning the game.

The game won second prize in the 2009 Hippodice Game Design Competition.

item.description: Sitcht oder nicht is a trick-taking game with two things that differentiate it from other titles in the genre: (1) The game uses four piles of special cards, with one card being revealed randomly from each pile. These cards provide bonuses or penalties for collecting the fewest tricks, cards of a particular color, whether the round has a trump, and so forth. However, only two of the four cards will be used in the round, with players choosing which ones. (2) Each player has a single +2/-2 card that can be played at the same time as another card to beat trump or dodge a trick you don't want.

name.value: Road Skill: Survival on Life's Great Highway

item.description:
You're a Squirrel! You live in the woods and eat nuts, but to get them you must cross the busy highway! Do you have the nerve to test your luck against the forces of Man and Nature?!

You don't have to be nuts to play this game, but it helps to have some!

It has been estimated that before the arrival of the White Man, there were billions of squirrels and a squirrel could travel by tree from the Atlantic to the Mississippi without ever touching the ground!

Well, time have changed! The trees are gone and roads crisscross the countryside. Life is tough on these hapless rodents as they attempt to navigate Man’s Asphalt Obstacles!

As you may have guessed, the object of this game is to gather as many nuts as possible and get them home without becoming a Furry Flapjack! You will need a bag of Nuts. Of course, you could use pennies or other objects, but for the true Wilderness Experience, nuts are essential!

The first player to get home with nuts wins, and won’t starve to death next winter!

Can you survive a night in a house filled with ghastly terror? Play Paníque & find out!

Pronounce it "Pan-EEEK!"

The will of your late, eccentric millionaire uncle stipulates that in order for you to inherit his fortune, you - along with the other surviving relatives - must spend a night in his creepy, old, haunted death-trap of a house. Whoever is still alive when the morning comes can share the old man's millions... all others still inside of the house are sadly, declared dead!

Can you survive until morning?

name.value: Heavenly Ham House: The Safe-Sex Virtual-Reality Role-Playing Game!!

item.description:

A very silly PG-17 game by underground cartoonist Lloyd Dangle. One of the ten very limited silk screen game boards produced by Wild Wigout Comix Game Boards (less than 100 of each game was produced).

item.description:
It's time to relive all of your favorite battles from the ever popular kid's show Power Rangers!!!

Each player shuffles their Deck and cuts their opponent's Deck.

Turn Flow

STEP 1: Each player draws a card from the top of their Deck to their hand.

STEP 2: Each player can then choose to select a card from their hand, if available.

STEP 3: In order to play a card in battle, a player must fulfill the Hand Cost requirement located on that card (see Symbol ). To do this, a player removes a specified number of cards from their hand to their “Discard Pile” that is equal to the amount indicated by Symbol . If the Hand Cost requirement can’t be met, that card can’t be played.

STEP 4: Each player then puts down the card they have chosen for battle on the count of three. “1..2..3!”. (For strategic purposes, players have the option of bluffing their opponent by not putting down a card at the count of three.)

STEP 5: If a player plays a card and their opponent does not, the player inflicts “Damage” to their opponent (see Step 6C). If neither player plays a card, nothing happens and both players return to Step 1.

STEP 6: When both players have played a card, the battle begins!

A.Each player must refer to Symbol on their card which indicates the Battle Element that each player’s opponent will be using for this battle. If a player’s card has multiple Battle Elements listed here, the player has the option to choose any one of them.

B.Each player now looks at the value indicated on their chosen Battle Element (See Symbol ). The player with the higher value wins the battle! (If the values are equal, it is considered a “draw” and both players return to Step 1). The winning player now gets to inflict “Damage” to their opponent.

C.When receiving Damage, the losing player must draw a number of cards from the top of their deck equal to the amount indicated on the winning player’s card (See Symbol ). Move all used cards to their Discard Pile.
Winning the Game

Repeat Steps 1 through 6 until a player is required to draw a card and cannot due to a lack of cards in their Deck.

That player loses the game. If both players must draw a card and cannot due to a lack of cards in their Decks, the game result is a “Draw”.

(From the box) An exciting word game for teens/adults.

Roll the die. Land on a question category. Answer a question. Score points. Frustrate your opponent's play.

"Word Challenge" is a fast-paced word relationship game designed for teenagers and adults. Winning requires a combination of knowledge, strategy and luck.

The objective is to score 800 points by answering in one of five categories of word relationships.

The game consists of 3,000 questions and 17,000 words or phrases. It can be played more than twenty-five (25) times without repeating questions.

Stack the tile up into a single stack. This game is an adaptation of the traditional card solitaire game of the same name. A turn in the game is performed by drawing a new tile, using it to create a new stack at the right end of the line and then moving stacks of tiles, placing them on the top of stacks to their left in the line.

A fast-moving category game in which the idea is to be Catcher and catch players out by saying their word three times before they can once.

One player is the Catcher. The others are assigned four chips and a random word in one of six categories. Each player announces his word to the Catcher, who repeats it and memorizes it before moving on to the next player. Once all players have announced their word, the round begins immediately. The Catcher tries to say anybody's word three times in rapid succession before that player can respond by saying his own word once. If the Catcher is successful, the "caught" player discards a chip and the round continues. Once one player has lost all three chips the round ends, and players score a point for each chip remaining. The player who lost all his chips becomes the new Catcher. The game ends when a player reaches a pre-determined score.

Schweinebande (literally "Gang of Pigs") was published in February 2010 by Hans im Glück.

The board depicts a cattle market, on which pigs, goats, donkeys, chickens, and other animals are offered for sale. Each player tries to position his farmers strategically in order to obtain the most favorable prices, or to block his competitors. Once animals are acquired, they must be fed every round. As soon as a player possesses 4 of the same animals, he can sell his herd to gain victory points. Naturally, a set of 4 donkeys is worth more than 4 chickens.

More cards can be bought as booster packs, so this is basically a CCG, but the starter set has enough cards for two players to play the game.

Complete the Zoofari by matching as many sets of paw prints as possible. Deck of 52 cards with single or double paw prints in different colors. Optional play includes 2 WILD cards which automatically give the player a match.

name.value: TinkerBell Pardon My Pixie Dust Game

item.description:
From the box: Help TinkerBell and her friends get ready for Spring! Collect all the "Get ready for Spring cards" as you travel around Pixie Hollow. But don't forget your Pixie Dust... you need it to win!

Publisher: Printed under license by Cardinal. UPC 0-47754-17169-3

Theme: Disney Fairies, game for young children.

Contents: 4 playing pieces (each a different color), 16 cards (4 types: light, flower, animal, water), board, die, Pixie Dust card

Goal: Be the first player to collect all 4 types of cards (light, flower, animal, water) AND the only Pixie Dust card.

Game-Play: Roll the die and move around the board. Landing on the light, flower, animal or water fairy will allow you to take that type of card. You need one of each. There are spaces on the board that allow you to take one of these cards from another player. Also, there are Pixie Dust spaces. Landing on one of these allows you to take the Pixie Dust card (there is only one) from the other player. You need all 4 types of cards plus the Pixie Dust card to win.

name.value: Body Count: Five Battles in Vietnam 1965–1969

item.description:
Body Count is a new Tactical Combat Series game that covers five actions in Vietnam starting with the earliest actions of the US (Operation Starlite and LZ X-Ray) through air cavalry actions (Operation Pegagus), Vietnamization (Duc Lap) and finally assaults on fortified areas (Hamburger Hill).

5 maps (small) + 5 area movement maps
720 counters

Unit size: single vehicles, weapons sections, infantry platoons
Hex scale: 125 yards
Turn: 20 minutes

Special rules:
Napalm
Flare Ships
FACs
Broken Arrow
Helicopter transport
Helicopter gunships
Tunnel complexes
RPGs
Claymores
NVA/VC concealment

Contents:
Wobbly board
20 taxis
8 sided die

20 taxis are divided equally among players. In turn, each player rolls the die and either places one of their taxis on the indicated color (or any color if the "?" is rolled) or takes a taxi from each of the other players (if the police officer is rolled). First player to get rid of all their taxis wins.

This game can be played as a stand-alone game or can be used in conjunction with any monopoly game. Special rules for playing with classic Monopoly are included.

name.value: Monopoly: New York Yankees World Series Champions Collector's Edition

item.description:
Publisher Blurb:

2009 World Series® Champions!

The Yankees take the title! Here’s your opportunity to own the 27-time World Series winning team, the New York Yankees. Relive the playoffs as you play the game and honor Mariano Rivera’s stellar pitching, Alex Rodriguez’s exceptional hitting and Joe Girardi’s great coaching. Own the best of the Yankees and their historic season as you buy, sell and trade Mark Teixeira, Hideki Matsui and Derek Jeter in this classic game of risk taking and deal making. Game includes six collectible tokens: World Series trophy, Catcher’s mask, Batter, Pitcher, Ball in glove and a Hot dog.

Ages 8+
2-6 players

There’s a new mayor in town! And he’s here to change things!
On the order of the day: Privatise transports.
He put together a team to redesign the city’s main lanes, and he now needs enterprising volunteers to achieve it. 
And they only got 4 years to do it!

Each player will represent the CEO of a Private Mass Transport company, trying to achieve high value for their shares in the stock market, and a healthy bank account. The City needs a new transport grid, either with Bus or Metro Lines.
The players will achieve that by building segments of Transport Lines connecting the objectives as dictated by public surveys. Also, the City Hall will come up with special projects, which will be bided by the players.
The game turns are split into Quarters (3 months), in which everyone does their actions. After all players had a turn, the Quarter advances, players receive profit (or not!), and the first player of the Quarter changes (so that everyone can have a quarter in which they are the first to build).
After all Quarters are done, the Year advances and players tally up their accomplishments that year, which will directly impact their Stock Market EOY results.
By the end of the fourth year, the city should be fully networked, and we’ll have a happy Mayor, ready to win the next elections. The player that had the most impact (somehow measured by the value of the shares), will be given the key to the city!

That easy?
Not really. Not everything goes as planned, strange events occur, people lie, politicians cheat…. 
At the beginning of every quarter something will happen that can change a smile into a frown. Or the other way around… 
And there’s also the Influence that such powerful transport tycoons (the players) will have on politics!

Who knows, sometime in four years, you might be the one smiling in front of the cameras holding a golden key to the city!
Or you could be the one already planning for revenge…

Either way, fun is coming your way!

"Rock the Wizard"

Splut! is an abstract strategy boardgame. It has a fantasy theme and the looks of a chessgame.

2 To 4 players compete in an arena where they each control a team consisting of one large Troll and one Dwarf, led by a Sorcerer as coach.

During your turn you have three moves to make with your pawns. Try to get your Troll to a Rock (four Rocks are provided in the arena) and let him throw it onto an opposing Sorcerer. This will eliminate that team.

By moving your pawns ingeniously around the board, you must take out all other players' Sorcerers. Push other pawns with your Dwarf, levitate Rocks into place with your Sorcerer and throw Rocks around the arena with your Troll. Mind your head!

item.description:
"Pur Week-End" is a French storytelling game in which players must discard cards to tell how awesome their week-end was, while trying to spoil their opponents' week-ends.

The active player makes up a consistent story of his imaginary week-end by playing sets of 3 "Awesome Time" cards with matching symbols (for the time of the day). This could lead to surprising events : try to imagine a morning activity involving "Foam Bath" AND "Practical Joke" AND "Shared Secret"…

Meanwhile, the other players can play "Awful Time" cards to spoil their opponent's good time, as long as they manage to have it make sense with the story. The active player may then defend himself with a special card ("Magical Moment", "Wish Come True" or "Heroic Action"), or even deflect the trouble back with "Revenge".

And if you can't live awesome times on your own, you can always crash other players' events !

The winner is the first player who plays a set of cards for each of the 4 times of the day : morning, afternoon, evening and night.

The game contains 65 "Awesome Times", 18 "Aweful Times", 6 different "Magical Times" and a few special cards.

(Translations of card names in this description are not official)

item.description:
Originally called 'Dammen voor 4'.

Translated box text:

Checkers for 4 is much more than just checkers: young, old, novice or expert, everybody can play! Play individually or 2-against-2 and prepare for a dynamic family game full of surprises...

1. Everybody's in!
Whether playing with two, three or four players, everybody is in with Checkers for 4! Ideal for families and friends, at home or on holiday.

2. Individual and team play
Go for the challenge: Play individually and go head to head, in pairs with players from different levels or gang up to defeat the so-called 'Checkers King'!

3. Great introduction to checkers
Checkers for 4 is a fun way to get introduced to the game of checkers. The classic rules still apply and you can team up to play against a single experienced player. Learn and win at the same time!

4. A challenge for checkers experts
More opponents from varying levels on a single board requires good analysis, prediction en constantly adapting your style of play. In short, a real challenge for experienced players.

The game consists of 3 Sub-games that are all played on a map of the Ladin valleys. In the very heart of the Dolomites live slightly more than 30.000 Ladins whose identity is characterised mainly by the uniqueness of their language which derives from Vulgar Latin. It is only thanks to the isolation of the splendid high-mountain landscape, in which the Ladins live, that the Ladin language and cultural heritage have survived.

1) Ladinoscop
The objective of the game is to connect the starting point and the arrival point indicated on the route card using the town tokens which lies between.

2) The Dolomite round trip
The objective of this game is to complete the Dolomites round trip by returning to the starting point.

3) Up and down trough Ladinia
The objective of the third game is to reach all the spaces corresponding to the taken town tokens, and finally return to the starting point.

A cooperative card game about distribution of various animals amongst players. Players collect sets of animals, but some do not get along with others. Incomplete sets go to the rival zoo. The player with the lowest score has to beat the rival zoo in order for everyone to win.

You have to travel trough Südtirol (its a province in the north of Italy) and gather money, possessions and figures.
After fixing the duration of the match and then you start your journey trough the land. 
To gather money you have to answer correctly to trivia cards about Südtirol or just hit the right field, same for possessions.

Easy to learn, fun to play if you live there.

link.value: Ideen-Werkstatt KG, des Klaus Wagner & Co

item.description:
Chrono Cat's is a French card game about important historical dates : Julius Caesar's victory in Alésia, Charlemagne's coronation, Gutenberg's first press, the discovery of America, the storming of the Bastille, WWI's armistice, the EEC Treaty of Rome.

The game was originally designed to help students to learn 52 important dates for a junior high school exam.
 
Rules

Each player get a deck of face-down "Event/Cat" cards.
The 52 "Date/Mouse" cards are spread on the table, dates up.

At his/her turn, a player draws a card from his/her deck and reads the event on this card. The other player then try to gain this event card by being the first to slam the matching date card (if no one finds the right date, the event card is just put aside).

When all the event cards have been read, the player with the most cards wins the game.

item.description:
A game for quick eyes and fast fingers.
A player roll the 3 special dice (on with colored squares for the frame, one with colored circles for the background and one with symbols for the item) and everyone must quickly combine the results and try to be the first to point the right tile.

Many variants are possible.

Content :
4 boards
3 special dice
29 chips
1 X chip

Contents:
95 Hollywood Domino Tiles
Hollywood Star with Platform
Red Carpet
8 Movie Markers
Mr. Hollywood Domino Marker
Scorepad
Rules booklet

Object of the game: To be the first to "complete your movie" by playing all of your domino tiles. To win the game, have the lowest total points after 13 rounds of play.

The game is played in 13 rounds beginning in a round that starts with a double 12 and ending in a round that starts with a double 0. On each turn, players attempt to play one of their domino tiles to match the number of a tile in play either in their own lane (their movie), on the Red Carpet lane (a collaborative movie), or on any lane with an opponent's Movie Marker (to make a "cameo appearance" in that movie). Special tiles include The Blockbuster which allows a player to place as many tiles as they can in that lane in a single turn, The Stunt Double which allows a player to play any tile of their choosing, and The Comeback which allows the player in posession of this tile at the end of the round to reduce their score to that of the lowest-scoring player for that round. The player with the fewest points at the end of 13 rounds is the winner.

Most men only distinguish among 11 basic colours (mango, lemon, mandarin, pistachio et al are things you eat, not colours. Oranges are a mere coincidence with the colour).

Rainbow++++ is a fast-paced card game where you must play at least one of each of the 11 possible colours in order to win.

Each colour has a unique special ability that can be good or bad and there is a universal special ability that says that any two played cards of the same colour act as a trump card of the colour of your choice.

The cunning player will carefully choose the sequence of cards to be played as a combo and try to avoid to play cards with a negative special ability.

item.description:
From the publisher's website:

"Desert War Egypt, 1940, is a game covering Italy’s invasion of Egypt, before Rommel came to rescue them from their folly. This game uses an updated, and slightly expanded, version of the MedWar Sicily game system: no CRT, just dice, and cards...a totally new approach to gaming battles that can be learned in five minutes and played in 2-3 hours.

Most of the rules and mechanics will be familiar to anyone who has ever played a wargame. Richard Berg however, has added to this simplicity a combat system that rates units for how many dice they get to roll on their behalf, as well as what kind of dice (small arms or Heavy Weapons).

The game also uses cards, one deck (of 10) for each player (whose cards are somewhat different from those of the other player) to enhance the game. (They don't "drive" the game and they can be left out, if you’re so inclined.) The cards are part of a Resource system that gives the players a number of points which they can use to buy cards, rally units or bring in reinforcements. The choice is theirs, but there are far more choices than points.

The cards, themselves, give the players "Opportunities", from using their (or negating their opponent’s) tank capabilities, to getting more supplies, to special Breakthrough and Reaction movement.

Playing time for “Desert War Egypt” as averaged less than 3 hours, and the rules are only 8 pages, including rules for playing Solitaire.

Each game of Desert War Egypt includes full box, rules, one sheet of large 5/8” die cut thick counters, dice, two decks of 10 cards, and a thick card stock game board.

According to the back of the box, the game will include new and updated counters for MedWar Sicily, the first game using this system. Upcoming games using this system include East War Russia 1941, and Guns of August 1914.

item.description:
Dominion is played on a 8×8 square board.
On each turn, each player must do one of the following things:

 Drop a stone on a empty cell.
 Jump a stone to an empty cell.
 Pass its turn if he cannot drop or jump.




When all cells are occupied, the player with more stones wins.

Have you ever wondered what it would be like to step into your favorite giant monster suit and go on a rampage? Well now's your chance! Giant Monster Rampage is a turn based combat game for two or more players set in a world where giant monsters really exist. The game allows players to create and control one of several different types of monsters, from mutant animals to alien robots and everything in between. Giant Monster Rampage is unique in that it gives players complete control over the creation of their monster. Players can create an existing monster from popular media or one from their own imagination. The possibilities are endless. The object of the game is simply to cause as much damage and destruction as possible.

Giant Monster Rampage is a stand alone game that can also be used as an expansion for any other Toy Battle System™ game.

Power Warriors is a turn based combat game for two or more players set in a world where an alien race is trying to enslave the Earth. The planet's only hope for survival is a group of young warriors. The game allows players to create and control a mighty warrior trained to fight using the mystical energy of life known as qi. Power Warriors is unique in that it gives players complete control over the creation of their warrior. Players can create an existing warrior from popular media or one from their own imagination. The possibilities are endless. The object of the game is simply to be the last warrior standing.

Power Warriors is a stand alone game that can also be used as an expansion for any other Toy Battle SystemTM game.

Mix´n´Match is played on a 7x7 square board.
The board is occupied by stones except the middle cell.
The Mix player must jump on any orthogonal or diagonal direction and capture stones if they are different from each other.
The match player must jump on any orthogonal or diagonal direction and capture stones if they have the same color.
The player that cannot make any valid move,loses.

item.description:
Jumping Beans is played on a 7x7 square board.
The board is occupied by beans except the middle cell.
Each player starts with 24 beans.
Beans may move to an adjacent empty cell.
Beans capture by jumping over an enemy bean. Capturing is mandatory, and you must keep jumping and capturing as long as it is possible.
A player wins when it captures all enemy beans or when he moves his last remaining bean to the center cell.

item.description: Par Golf from National Games published in the 1950's is described on the game cover as a 'fascinating,authentic, new GOLF GAME'.

Chameleons is played on a 7x7 square board.
The board is occupied by Chameleons except the middle cell.
Each player starts with 24 Chameleons on his color.
A Chameleon may move to any adjacent empty cell.
A Chameleon that remains on a different color for more than one round will change itself to match that color.
The central cell is always considered to be the opposite color of the Chameleon that occupies it.
A Chameleon captures by jumping over an enemy Chameleon.
Captures are multiple and compulsory.
The player that captures or converts all enemy Chameleons wins.

The game of Tennis from National Games circa 1940's. In this tennis game one uses a die and a pawn to represent the tennis ball which players try to rally back and forth over the net. Throw too small a number, and your ball wouldn’t make it over the net. Too big a number, and you would overshoot the back line.

"Card and Dice Game for 2-6 players. Greek City State Theme."

The players compete for control of ten Greek city states. The first player to control four cities or collect 100 victory tokens wins the game.

This free, online rules set describes the components that you will need to create in order to play.

This game circa the 1930's was Law & Order type game with players playing either the good guys or the bad guys. The personality of each of the bad guys was different allowing for slightly different rules for each.

A card game based on the Prince Valiant comic strip.

This free, online rules set describes the components that you will need to create in order to play. The game requires a custom deck of approximately 120 cards and a set of coins or poker chips to use as Victory Tokens.

The deck is composed of seven types of cards: Trait, Plot, Location, Woman, Ally, Villain, and Foe. Players are awarded Victory Tokens for playing melds, with larger melds receiving more tokens. The first player to obtain ten Victory Tokens wins the game.

"Board and card game depicting the colonization of the Americas circa 1492-1760."

The players portray European powers (Spain, Portugal, France, England, and Holland) exploring the American continents. The map is randomly constructed during the course of play. Card play determines what actions a player can take each turn.

This free, online rules set describes the components that you will need to create in order to play the game. The components consist of an 8x5 grid board, 50 terrain tiles, approximately 170 cards, 39 Indian tribe counters, Gold tokens, and Victory Point tokens.

"Tile laying game for 2-4 players. Players are constructing a city of the Roman Empire."

The game is played on an 8x8 grid board such as a standard chess board. During the course of the game the players fill the board with tiles representing different structures and resources found in a Roman city.

The players score points based on various factors, including tile type and location. Control markers are used to denote which player played a tile to aid in scoring. The object is to have the most victory points once the board has been filled.

A stock market manipulation game, in which players move around a board buying, selling and trading stocks. In addition to the usual fluctuation of share values and events (from the 'Bulls' and 'Bears' cards), the game introduces more sophisticated ideas such as buying and calling stock options, margin buying, and cornering the market.

"The last battle of King Arthur, where Arthur was mortally wounded and Mordred was slain. Card game for 2 Players."

This free, online rules set describes the components that you will need to create in order to play. The game is played using a custom deck of approximately 50 cards. The cards represent individual knights, weapons, magic, troops, events, traits, and mortal wounds.

A series of ten hands are played. The winner is the first player to win three hands in a row, win six of the ten hands, or to kill the opponent's leader.

"War game for 2-6 players. Each player controls a civilization in the area of Asia Minor circa 1000 BCE. Each turn represents 10 years."

The players expand their competing civilizations across Asia Minor while amassing resources. Knowledge cards are purchased to help advance, benefit, or protect a player's civilization. Random event cards generate unexpected bonuses or catastrophes.

This is a free, online rules set which describes the components that you will need to create in order to play. Components include an area movement map of Asia Minor, seven sets of uniquely colored counters, six player resource mats, a victory point track consisting of 100 spaces, two custom decks of cards, and six and ten sided dice. An area movement map is available for download from the Warp Spawn site.

From the rules:

"Escalation is a game simulating political and military struggle during the cold war. The object of the game is to accumulate 20 VP by controlling Strategic Theatres. Competition on a Strategic Theatre could be started by triggering a local Crisis. Control over a Strategic Theatre could be gained using political means. Or, if you are a ruthless warmonger, you can make the guns roar. Or even start a nuclear weapon race."

Escalation is a print and play card game. Components include a custom deck of cards (composed of Crisis, Political, Special, and War Unit Cards) and a set of Strategic Theater boards (Europe, Middle East, Asia, Africa, North America, South America, U.N. Council, Sea Control, and Nuclear Weapons Race).

This trivia game is played in two stages: you compete first to acquire rings in the Olympic colours, then to acquire bronze and silver medals before winning. Questions are read from cards or, optionally, provided by a DVD with images, video clips and further reading. There are more than 2000 questions in all.

Players roll dice then flip a card that directs them to complete one of four different activities that incorporate the Cranium themed dice:

1. Complete sentences by spelling words with letters on rolled dice.
2. Doing simple math problems with numbers on dice.
3. Finding dice with specific pictures on them.
4. Creating a sculpture out of cards and dice.

Game was created for and sold exclusively through Starbucks during the 2009-2010 Holiday season

item.description:
Showdown! is a turn based card game. Each player starts with a leader that is out of play and five cards (max hand size). Two cards are drawn each turn and the players may play any number of soldiers and weapons on his/her turn. In order to attack another player's soldier he/she must have an attack card. The attacker chooses both his soldier and the target soldier and may disarm the target with a disarm card. The defender may respond at this point with a disarm if he/she has one. Each player in the fight rolls a die and adds up the bonuses from weapons, upgrades and one shot cards. The highest number wins with ties going to the defender. The loser may play a reroll card on his/her opponent if the player has one. Once three soldiers are in a players soldier discard pile, that players leader is in play and may attack. The leader may only be attacked if the player has no other soldiers out. Be the last one left with a leader in play and win the battle!

This card based battle game that will require both strategy and luck. Get ready to choose a side in this epic fight that will answer the question once and for all. Who's cooler?

This set combines Ninjas, Pirates, Knights and the Undead!

Play your soldiers! Protect your leaders! Equip them with weapons and accessories! Play attack cards on your opponents soldiers in order to clear the way to their leader. Roll the dice and add your bonuses and hope it's more than your opponent. He rolled a 6? Play your card that forces him to reroll! Why not disarm him before attacking next time? Do you have your base card that gives a bonus to all your soldiers? Find the weakest link and kick him while he's down!

Kill all your opponents leaders and be the last one standing to win!

From publisher's website:

"Get your family moving with the Eric Carle From Head to Toe Game! This game develops a child's self-esteem and confidence. Players flip over cards to see who can do various moves with their bodies like Can You Wiggle Your Hips? Everyone who answers I Can Do It! does the action. This game encourages imagination as children act out images on the cards, and coordination as children learn to move all parts of their bodies."

A game of ancient civilizations in conflict over the European continent and surrounding territories. "For 2-4+ players."

The players choose to play as one of 12 ancient civilizations of the region. Each civilization starts with two traits, such as arts, metallurgy, ship building, religion, etc. Traits provide certain resources or benefits. Traits can be developed and improved during the Research Phase.

Each territory on the map is marked with a type of resource. The distribution of the resources is randomly determined each game. Resources are used for various purposes, including supporting your civilization, building cities, and supporting research attempts.

This is a free, online rules set which describes the components that you will need to create in order to play. Components include an area movement map of Europe, a set of six tokens for each player (Armies, Fleets, Villages, Cities, Monuments, and Resources), a resource chart for each player, a common resource pool card, and six-, eight-, and twelve-sided dice. An area movement map is available for download from the Warp Spawn site.

From the rules:

"Rule the world in the XIX Century"

"This is the XIX Century. Industrialism is growing ruthlessly, while both Armies and Navies are equipped with increasingly efficient weapons. The Minor Nations are deprived of their Resources by cunning Diplomats, while the Major Powers become richer and more powerful. Empires struggle for supremacy both in the Military and the Economy spheres."

"Gold, Blood and Iron will determine the ultimate Ruler of the World!"

Imperialism is a print and play card game. Components include a custom deck of cards (composed of Territory, Work, Army, Navy, and News Cards), Warehouse tabletop cards for each player, a TradeBoard tabletop card, and a sets of revenue, resource, and item tokens.

Two to four (or more) players represent one of ten world civilizations (Middle East, North Africa, India, China, Meso America, etc.)

Each civilization is rated for ten attributes (Conquest, Trade, Culture, Science, Agriculture, Religion, Sea, Government, Equestrian, and Engineering). The value of each attribute is randomly determined by rolling a die at the start of the game, with each civilization receiving a second cumulative die roll for a specified attribute in which that civilization excelled.

The gameplay involves drawing and trading cards in order to play melds. Playing a meld adds to a player's victory point total and increases the value of an attribute of the player's civilization. Playing a meld also conveys a specific bonus (such as stealing cards or victory points from other players) depending on the type of meld played. The winner is the player with the most victory points after twelve rounds have been played.

This free, online rules set describes the components that you will need to create in order to play. The components include a custom card deck made up of twelve types of cards with nine copies of each card. Six-sided dice are also required for play.

name.value: Moongha Invaders: Mad Scientists and Atomic Monsters Attack the Earth!

item.description:
It's just another day, get up, wash, go to work. What's different is that today the Earth has been invaded by aliens – it's just that nobody knows it yet. Deep underground mad scientists are raising monsters from the planet Moongha. Once fully formed they will emerge to spread terror and destruction. Cities will be laid waste to, and the human race will be hunted to extinction.

Through the sewers oozes the Bloob, quietly growing in size. The Drakoor, alien vampires, stalk the night, feeding off the unwary. Meanwhile, the strongest of the Moongha invaders, Mechoor, sucks in energy from the earth. Once sated it will rise to destroy whole cities with its heat ray. These are just a few of the monsters that will terrorise the people of Earth.

It can only be hoped that just as in the movies there's a hero around who can thwart their evil plans; otherwise there will be no more "just another day"s for anybody! But who's behind those evil plans? You! You are one of those sadistic, power-thirsty, psycho nerds, eager for revenge after a whole life of study, disregarded by everyone. All of you have received a visit from a mysterious flying saucer, carrying strange alien machinery – an engine that finally brought you POWER! And now you are ready to fight your insane struggle to be the first in destroying the human race. This time no "Klaatu barada nikto!" will stop you...

Moongha Invaders: Mad Scientists and Atomic Monsters Attack the Earth! is for three to four players and should take about ninety minutes to play. You have control of a number of different types of Moongha monsters. When you sit down to play, the side of the board closest to you is your monster display. There you will see the seven different types of monster. You will place your monster counters in these boxes. Note that some monster types have more than one counter.

The game lasts either eight or nine turns, depending on the number of players, although it may end before then if a player manages to get down all twenty of their damage cubes.

At the start of each turn a random number of actions are made available. Three of these actions relate to the monsters and allow you to create, attack, and move them. These actions are represented by orange, white, and purple tokens. There are three human action boxes, one that allows you to place a hero, the other two allow you to place military counters.

To create a monster you have to place a certain number of orange tokens in the monster box. Once the monster has been created you place it in one of the twelve cities on the board. When you do so, you place the monster on its hidden side. The monster is alive but as yet the world does not know of its presence. While hidden a monster is safe from attack and can build up its strength so that when it does attack it will cause carnage. Another player may attempt to reveal your monster by placing a hero counter in the same city.

Military units will try to destroy monsters. When you place a military unit or a hero, you can then attack with all military counters in that city. When a monster attacks a city, armor units will attack it first, then after that attack has been completed, any surviving infantry units will attack. All combat involves rolling dice and in all cases a roll of four or more is successful.

Each monster type has its own special abilities. Only three monsters are powerful enough to destroy entire cities; these are the Bloob, Mechoor, and Moogre. When you attack a city, you mark the damage you do with your colored cubes. At the end of the game, players score victory points depending on how many damage cubes they have in each city. Players also score points for the cities that were randomly assigned to them at the beginning of the game, depending on how much damage they have suffered. Points can also be scored for having vampires on the board and for killing other monsters with your Moogre monster.

item.description:
A web-published board game of European conflict between the Great Powers. Inspired by the game Diplomacy.

From the publisher's website:

"Heavily modified variant of the board game Diplomacy. Card play replaces written orders. Players should be familiar with basic concepts of the standard game such as Supply Centers, Provinces, Units, and Great Powers. Special movement rules (Kiel & Constantinople, etc.) still apply. Rules for Retreats, Building, Occupation, Civil Disorder, and Convoys still work in the spirit of the original game."

"The standard game takes place in the relatively peaceful (historically) period between the Franco Prussian War (also Russo-Turkish) and WWI. However, it will be noticed that the card flavor of the Battle Decks in this variant has a distinctly WWI flavor."

"Rail Road Building Theme. Pen and Paper Game: No cards or dice needed. This is a modified PnP version of Railroad Dispatch USA."

The game is played on a map of the United States marked with cities. The players build rail connections by drawing lines between the cities. Building rail lines is one of the means of acquiring Victory Points. Additional Victory Points are scored when the player duplicates the circuit covered by historical rail lines.

The game adds additional flavor to this basic framework through the Income, Research, and Stock Points tracked for each player's railway. A series of Events can affect these point values as well, based on historical events that influenced nineteenth rail travel in the United States.

The Income, Research, and Stock Point values also serve to increase a player's Victory Point total. Victory Points can also be scored based on the type of commodities produced in the cities connected to a player's rail lines.

Materials required for play: Two pens with different colored ink, a coin, a printout of the game map, and a copy of the scoring tables.

Patzam is a sort of moving 3D Tic Tac Toe where you remove the middle piece each time you make a row. The goal of the game is to get rid of your pieces and be the first to have only 2 left.

Rules:
Alternately, both players place one piece on one of the 18 spots of the 3D-board. When all the pieces have been played, middle pieces of any rows of the same color are removed.
Then, players successively slide one piece in order to make a row (and remove the middle piece) or block the opponent.
The first player who has only 2 of his own pieces left on the board is the winner.

Komikan is a two-player abstract strategy board game from the Mapuches of Chile.

Rules
It is a hunt game using an expanded Alquerque board. Like all hunt games, there are two unequal forces at play. In Komikan, one player has only a single piece (usually called a "puma", "jaguar", "komikelu", "leon" or "ukuku"), which can move one space at a time or capture the other player's pieces by hopping over them.
The other player has twelve pieces (usually called "sheeps", "goats", "dogs" or "kukulis"), that can only move one space at a time, but not capture, and attempts only to surround and immobilize the puma or jaguar. All pieces must move and/or capture following the pattern on the board.

Board
The expanded Alquerque board consist of an Alquerque board and a triangular patterned board attached on one of its side. The sheeps or goats can also win the game by occupying every spaces on this triangle.
There are different triangular patterned board designs attached to the Alquerque board, and therefore Komikan has several variants. The standard triangular board has one horizontal line across the breadth of the triangle, and one vertical line along the length of the triangle.

According to Wikipedia, "Komikan may actually be the same game as Adugo."

Players compete to purchase vineyards along the Italian peninsula.
By exploiting their own lands, they will produce wine with which they will realize the revenue necessary to develop their own activities.
Who will become the most famous?

The game is played in 6 turns.

Each turn is divided into 3 phases: 
1. The arrangement of the turn
2. The choice of actions
3. The development of actions

The arrangement of the turn
Put 6 land cards on the table: get the first 4 from the stacks corresponding to the specific grape varieties. 
Get the last 2 from the shared deck. These will be the lands that can be purchased in the turn.
For the successive turns, update the prices increasing the highest price to 7 and use the same gap for all other prices.

The choice of actions
Every player starting from the first will be able to do some actions. There is only one limit to the actions that can be done in a turn: that is the money necessary to do them.
These actions, that can be found on the corresponding table of the game board, are: 
Modify the game order for the next turn 
Turn a land into a DOCG area (where DOCG stays for “Denomination of origin inspected and guaranteed”)
Benefit from the events
Purchase the lands revealed on the turn
Develop your own production capacity (quantity)
Develop your general productive quality
Make one of your vineyards productive 


The development of actions
All the actions choosed before will be acted in the game, in the exact order of them.


End of the game
The game ends at the end of the sixth turn.
In the last turn some bonus fame points will be distributed. 
More specifically: fame points to the player who has got more points on the bonus vine production, fame points to the player who has got more lands for each of the 4 macro-areas, fame points to the player with more money, fame point for each line of the technological development equal to 3.


The winner is who has got more fame points.

item.description:
This game is played with a joker and 6-Ace in four suits from a standard deck of cards. Each of the three players is dealt 12 cards and bids by discarding three cards simultaneously. The suit of those cards show how many points they bid, and the highest bidder has to take card-points in tricks as close as possible to his bid.

Reimplements: Ninety-Nine

This game is played with a standard deck of cards. The novelty in this otherwise simple trick-taking game is that one of the players (partnerships) decides the trumps, then the other decides the top (for example if 8 is the top then the ranking order of cards from high to low is 8765432AKQJ109 in each suit).

The Horror is a turn based combat set in a world where a mob of horrifying creatures (zombies, skeletons, or whatever you want) have overrun the world and the remaining survivors are just trying to live another day. The game can be played solo or with a group of friends.

The game allows players to create and control a survior trying to make good his escape from the horror infested playing field.

The object of the game can be as simple as getting from side of the playing field to the other alive or as complex as completeing several objectives before being allowed to escape.

Panzer Clash is a light, card-based wargame about Second World War Panzer battles for 2 - 4 players.

Pick a side, either Axis or Allies, and build a deck of 40 cards out of a pool of 100 different cards in order to defeat your enemey.
The deck or Supply contains Factories, Units, Events and Terrain Modifiers. Factories are needed to build Units and Terrain Modifiers as well as to power Events. Units and Events, which usually belong to one or more of the four factions (Germans, Japanese, Americans and Soviets) are used to attack and deal damage to the opponent, have certain beneficial effects on the game or are used to weaken the opponent. For each point of damage a Player receives through Units and Events, he or she puts one card from his or her Supply (deck) onto his or her Junkyard (discard-pile). Is a player unable to draw a card from the Supply, he or she loses immediately.

This game started out as a retheme of my fantasy card game Elemental Clash and ended up being so much more...

Very special thanks to my historic advisor Bruno Abreu!!

This game is played with a standard deck of cards including two jokers. Both players are dealt four cards and a card is put face up on the table players put their cards so they form at the end of the round a 3x3 grid. Then one player scores for the vertical, the other for the horizontal lines. The score depends on the cards in the row, but cards with the same color or suit increases the value of a line.

More information, including a 3 and a 4-player variant can be found at http://parlettgames.uk/oricards/dracula.html

Up to three players control mini-golfers and try to putt their golf balls onto a rotating golf course that contains a water trap, sand trap, 4 greens (valued 2,3,4, & 5 points), and a windmill on a green in the center. Players try to earn the most points.

A fantastic challenge for shockaholics or quiz addicts, Shocking Quiz lets you test your general knowledge with this 4 player multiple choice quiz game. And if you don’t know the correct answer to one of the 600 questions your in for a shock....quite literally!
